p: Although the link between phenotypic plasticity and distribution has not been comprehensively supported (Dawson et al. 2012), phenotypic plasticity clearly contributes to environmental tolerance in various ways (e.g. Ghalambor et al. 2007; Des Marais et al. 2013; Schilthuizen and Kellermann 2014). Moreover, at least under conditions of resource abundance, it appears that invasive species do show greater plasticity than their indigenous counterparts (Davidson et al. 2011), although the way in which such comparisons should be made has been the subject of much recent discussion (Van Kleunen et al. 2010; Leffler et al. 2014).
